Tensions over rising Polish nationalism and the economic effects of the Continental System led to renewed confrontation with Russia. To enforce his blockade, Napoleon launched an invasion of Russia in the summer of 1812. The resulting campaign witnessed the catastrophic collapse of the Grand Army, forcing the French to retreat, as well as leading to the widespread destruction of Russian lands and cities. In 1813, Prussia and Austria joined Russian forces in a Sixth Coalition against France. A chaotic military campaign in Central Europe eventually culminated in a large Allied army defeating Napoleon at the Battle of Leipzig in October. The next year, the Allies invaded France and captured Paris, forcing Napoleon to abdicate in April 1814. He was exiled to the island of Elba. The Bourbons were restored to power and the French lost most of the territories that they had conquered since the Revolution. However, Napoleon escaped from Elba in February 1815 and took control of the government once again. The Allies responded by forming

In the Hesiodic Catalogue of Women, Graecus is presented as the son of Zeus and Pandora II, sister of Hellen the patriarch of Hellenes. Hellen was the son of Deucalion who ruled around Phthia in central Greece. The Parian Chronicle mentions that when Deucalion became king of Phthia, the previously called Graikoi were named Hellenes. Aristotle notes that the Hellenes were related with Grai/Greeks (Meteorologica I.xiv) a native name of a Dorian tribe in Epirus which was used by the Illyrians. He also claims that the great deluge must have occurred in the region around Dodona, where the Selloi dwelt. However, according to the Greek tradition it is more possible that the homeland of the Greeks was originally in central Greece. A modern theory derives the name Greek (Latin Graeci) from Graikos, "inhabitant of Graia/Graea," a town on the coast of Boeotia. Greek colonists from Graia helped to found Cumae (900 BC) in Italy,

In biology, energy is an attribute of all biological systems from the biosphere to the smallest living organism. Within an organism it is responsible for growth and development of a biological cell or an organelle of a biological organism. Energy is thus often said to be stored by cells in the structures of molecules of substances such as carbohydrates (including sugars), lipids, and proteins, which release energy when reacted with oxygen in respiration. In human terms, the human equivalent (H-e) (Human energy conversion) indicates, for a given amount of energy expenditure, the relative quantity of energy needed for human metabolism, assuming an average human energy expenditure of 12,500 kJ per day and a basal metabolic rate of 80 watts. For example, if our bodies run (on average) at 80 watts, then a light bulb running at 100 watts is running at 1.25 human equivalents (100 ÷ 80) i.e. 1.25 H-e. From 1877 to 1878, the area suffered a rash of stagecoach robberies. Most notable, however, were the two holdups committed by masked road-agent William Whitney Brazelton. Brazelton held up two stages in the summer of 1878 near Point of Mountain Station approximately 17 mi (27 km) northwest of Tucson. John Clum, of Tombstone, Arizona fame was one of the passengers. Brazelton was eventually tracked down and killed on Monday August 19, 1878, in a mesquite bosque along the Santa Cruz River 3 miles (5 km) south of Tucson by Pima County Sheriff Charles A. Shibell and his citizen's posse. Brazelton had been suspected of highway robbery not only in the Tucson area, but also in the Prescott region and Silver City, New Mexico area as well. Brazelton's crimes prompted John J. Valentine, Sr. of Wells, Fargo & Co. to send special agent and future Pima County sheriff Bob Paul to investigate. In 633 AD, Rashidun Arabs invaded Iran and conquered it by 651 AD, largely converting Iranian people from their indigenous faiths of Manichaeism and Zoroastrianism to Sunni Islam. Arabic replaced Persian as the official language, while Persian remained the language of both ordinary people and of literature. Iran became a major contributor to the Islamic Golden Age, producing many influential scientists, scholars, artists, and thinkers. Establishment of the Safavid Dynasty in 1501, converted the Iranian people from Sunni Islam to Twelver Shia Islam, and made Twelver Shia Islam the official religion of Iran. Safavid conversion of Iran from Sunnism to Shiism marked one of the most important turning points in Iranian and Muslim history. Carolingian art was produced for a small group of figures around the court, and the monasteries and churches they supported. It was dominated by efforts to regain the dignity and classicism of imperial Roman and Byzantine art, but was also influenced by the Insular art of the British Isles. Insular art integrated the energy of Irish Celtic and Anglo-Saxon Germanic styles of ornament with Mediterranean forms such as the book, and established many characteristics of art for the rest of the medieval period. Surviving religious works from the Early Middle Ages are mostly illuminated manuscripts and carved ivories, originally made for metalwork that has since been melted down. Objects in precious metals were the most prestigious form of art, but almost all are lost except for a few crosses such as the Cross of Lothair, several reliquaries, and finds such as the Anglo-Saxon burial at Sutton Hoo and the hoards of Gourdon from Merovingian France, Guarrazar from

The brief peace in Europe allowed Napoleon to focus on the French colonies abroad. Saint-Domingue had managed to acquire a high level of political autonomy during the Revolutionary Wars, with Toussaint Louverture installing himself as de facto dictator by 1801. Napoleon saw his chance to recuperate the formerly wealthy colony when he signed the Treaty of Amiens. During the Revolution, the National Convention voted to abolish slavery in February 1794. Under the terms of Amiens, however, Napoleon agreed to appease British demands by not abolishing slavery in any colonies where the 1794 decree had never been implemented. The resulting Law of 20 May never applied to colonies like Guadeloupe or Guyane, even though rogue generals and other officials used the pretext of peace as an opportunity to reinstate slavery in some of these places. The Law of 20 May officially restored the slave trade to the Caribbean colonies, not slavery itself. The works of Virgil almost from the moment of their publication revolutionized Latin poetry. The Eclogues, Georgics, and above all the Aeneid became standard texts in school curricula with which all educated Romans were familiar. Poets following Virgil often refer intertextually to his works to generate meaning in their own poetry. The Augustan poet Ovid parodies the opening lines of the Aeneid in Amores 1.1.1–2, and his summary of the Aeneas story in Book 14 of the Metamorphoses, the so-called "mini-Aeneid", has been viewed as a particularly important example of post-Virgilian response to the epic genre. Lucan's epic, the Bellum Civile has been considered an anti-Virgilian epic, disposing with the divine mechanism, treating historical events, and diverging drastically from Virgilian epic practice. By the early 18th century, the Maratha Kingdom had transformed itself into the Maratha Empire under the rule of the Peshwas (prime ministers). In 1737, the Marathas defeated a Mughal army in their capital, Delhi itself in Battle of Delhi (1737). The Marathas continued their military campaigns against Mughals, Nizam, Nawab of Bengal and Durrani Empire to further extend their boundaries. Gordon explained how the Maratha systematically took control over new regions. They would start with annual raids, followed by collecting ransom from villages and towns while the declining Mughal Empire retained nominal control and finally taking over the region. He explained it with the example of Malwa region. Marathas built an efficient system of public administration known for its attention to detail. It succeeded in raising revenue in districts that recovered from years of raids, up to levels previously enjoyed by the Mughals. Throughout the history of the South Slavs, the vernacular, literary, and written languages (e.g. Chakavian, Kajkavian, Shtokavian) of the various regions and ethnicities developed and diverged independently. Prior to the 19th century, they were collectively called "Illyric", "Slavic", "Slavonian", "Bosnian", "Dalmatian", "Serbian" or "Croatian". As such, the term Serbo-Croatian was first used by Jacob Grimm in 1824, popularized by the Vienna philologist Jernej Kopitar in the following decades, and accepted by Croatian Zagreb grammarians in 1854 and 1859. At that time, Serb and Croat lands were still part of the Ottoman and Austrian Empires. Officially, the language was called variously Serbo-Croat, Croato-Serbian, Serbian and Croatian, Croatian and Serbian, Serbian or Croatian, Croatian or Serbian. By 1959, American observers believed that the Soviet Union would be the first to get a human into space, because of the time needed to prepare for Mercury's first launch. On April 12, 1961, the USSR surprised the world again by launching Yuri Gagarin into a single orbit around the Earth in a craft they called Vostok 1. They dubbed Gagarin the first cosmonaut, roughly translated from Russian and Greek as "sailor of the universe". Although he had the ability to take over manual control of his spacecraft in an emergency by opening an envelope he had in the cabin that contained a code that could be typed into the computer, it was flown in an automatic mode as a precaution; medical science at that time did not know what would happen to a human in the weightlessness of space. The island of Saint Helena has a total area of 122 km2 (47 sq mi), and is composed largely of rugged terrain of volcanic origin (the last volcanic eruptions occurred about 7 million years ago). Coastal areas are covered in volcanic rock and warmer and drier than the centre. The highest point of the island is Diana's Peak at 818 m (2,684 ft). In 1996 it became the island's first national park. Much of the island is covered by New Zealand flax, a legacy of former industry, but there are some original trees augmented by plantations, including those of the Millennium Forest project which was established in 2002 to replant part of the lost Great Wood and is now managed by the Saint Helena National Trust. In January 1938, Milt Gabler started recording for his new label, Commodore Records, and to allow for longer continuous performances, he recorded some 12-inch records. Eddie Condon explained: "Gabler realized that a jam session needs room for development." The first two 12-inch recordings did not take advantage of the extra length: "Carnegie Drag" was 3:15; "Carnegie Jump", 2:41. But at the second session, on April 30, the two 12-inch recordings were longer: "Embraceable You" was 4:05; "Serenade to a Shylock", 4:32. Another way around the time limitation was to issue a selection on both sides of a single record. Vaudeville stars Gallagher and Shean recorded "Mr. Gallagher and Mr. Shean", written by Irving and Jack Kaufman, as two sides of a 10-inch 78 in 1922 for Cameo. An obvious workaround for longer recordings was to release a set of records. However, asymmetry of causation can be observed in a non-arbitrary way which is not metaphysical in the case of a human hand dropping a cup of water which smashes into fragments on a hard floor, spilling the liquid. In this order, the causes of the resultant pattern of cup fragments and water spill is easily attributable in terms of the trajectory of the cup, irregularities in its structure, angle of its impact on the floor, etc. However, applying the same event in reverse, it is difficult to explain why the various pieces of the cup should fly up into the human hand and reassemble precisely into the shape of a cup, or why the water should position itself entirely within the cup. The causes of the resultant structure and shape of the cup and the encapsulation of the water by the hand within the cup are not easily attributable, as neither hand nor floor can achieve such formations of the cup or water. The state seemed at relative calm compared to the rest of the country due to its close ties to the United States until 1841. In 1843 the possibility of war was anticipated by the state government and it began to reinforce the defense lines along the political boundary with Texas. Supplies of weapons were sent to fully equip the military and took steps to improve efficiency at the presidios. Later, the Regimen for the Defenders of the Border were organized by the state which were made up of: light cavalry, four squads of two brigades, and a small force of 14 men and 42 officials at the price of 160,603 pesos per year. During the beginning of the 1840s, private citizens took it upon themselves to stop the commercial caravans of supplies from the United States, but being so far away from the large suppliers in central Mexico the caravan was allowed to continue in March 1844.

John treated the interdict as "the equivalent of a papal declaration of war". He responded by attempting to punish Innocent personally and to drive a wedge between those English clergy that might support him and those allying themselves firmly with the authorities in Rome. John seized the lands of those clergy unwilling to conduct services, as well as those estates linked to Innocent himself; he arrested the illicit concubines that many clerics kept during the period, only releasing them after the payment of fines; he seized the lands of members of the church who had fled England, and he promised protection for those clergy willing to remain loyal to him. In many cases, individual institutions were able to negotiate terms for managing their own properties and keeping the produce of their estates. By 1209 the situation showed no signs of resolution, and Innocent threatened to excommunicate John if he did not acquiesce to Langton's appointment. The Canadian football field is 150 yards (137 m) long and 65 yards (59 m) wide with end zones 20 yards (18 m) deep, and goal lines 110 yards (101 m) apart. At each goal line is a set of 40-foot-high (12 m) goalposts, which consist of two uprights joined by an 18 1⁄2-foot-long (5.6 m) crossbar which is 10 feet (3 m) above the goal line. The goalposts may be H-shaped (both posts fixed in the ground) although in the higher-calibre competitions the tuning-fork design (supported by a single curved post behind the goal line, so that each post starts 10 feet (3 m) above the ground) is preferred. In 1939, the Bureau began compiling a custodial detention list with the names of those who would be taken into custody in the event of war with Axis nations. The majority of the names on the list belonged to Issei community leaders, as the FBI investigation built on an existing Naval Intelligence index that had focused on Japanese Americans in Hawaii and the West Coast, but many German and Italian nationals also found their way onto the secret list. Robert Shivers, head of the Honolulu office, obtained permission from Hoover to start detaining those on the list on December 7, 1941, while bombs were still falling over Pearl Harbor. Mass arrests and searches of homes (in most cases conducted without warrants) began a few hours after the attack, and over the next several weeks more than 5,500 Issei men were taken into FBI custody. South Korea: The event was held in Seoul, which hosted the 1988 Summer Olympics, on April 27. Intended torchbearers Choi Seung-kook and Park Won-sun boycotted the event to protest against the Chinese government's crackdown in Tibet. More than 8,000 riot police were deployed to guard the 24-kilometre route, which began at Olympic Park, which was built when Seoul hosted the 1988 Summer Games. On the day of the torch relay in Seoul, Chinese students clashed with protesters, throwing rocks, bottles, and punches. A North Korean defector whose brother defected to China but was captured and executed by the DPRK, attempted to set himself on fire in protest of China's treatment of North Korean refugees. The deliberate or accidental hybridising of two or more species of closely related animals through captive breeding is a human activity which has been in existence for millennia and has grown in recent times for economic purposes. The number of successful interspecific mammalian hybrids is relatively small, although it has come to be known that there is a significant number of naturally occurring hybrids between forms or regional varieties of a single species.[citation needed] These may form zones of gradation known as clines. Indeed, the distinction between some hitherto distinct species can become clouded once it can be shown that they may not only breed but produce fertile offspring. Some hybrid animals exhibit greater strength and resilience than either parent. This is known as hybrid vigor. The existence of the mule (donkey sire; horse dam) being used widely as a hardy draught animal throughout ancient and modern history is testament to this. A number of novel ideas about religion developed with the Enlightenment, including Deism and talk of atheism. Deism, according to Thomas Paine, is the simple belief in God the Creator, with no reference to the Bible or any other miraculous source. Instead, the Deist relies solely on personal reason to guide his creed, which was eminently agreeable to many thinkers of the time. Atheism was much discussed, but there were few proponents. Wilson and Reill note that, "In fact, very few enlightened intellectuals, even when they were vocal critics of Christianity, were true atheists. Rather, they were critics of orthodox belief, wedded rather to skepticism, deism, vitalism, or perhaps pantheism." Some followed Pierre Bayle and argued that atheists could indeed be moral men. BYU has 21 NCAA varsity teams. Nineteen of these teams played mainly in the Mountain West Conference from its inception in 1999 until the school left that conference in 2011. Prior to that time BYU teams competed in the Western Athletic Conference. All teams are named the "Cougars", and Cosmo the Cougar has been the school's mascot since 1953. The school's fight song is the Cougar Fight Song. Because many of its players serve on full-time missions for two years (men when they're 18, women when 19), BYU athletes are often older on average than other schools' players. The NCAA allows students to serve missions for two years without subtracting that time from their eligibility period. Of major Canadian cities, St. John's is the foggiest (124 days), windiest (24.3 km/h (15.1 mph) average speed), and cloudiest (1,497 hours of sunshine). St. John's experiences milder temperatures during the winter season in comparison to other Canadian cities, and has the mildest winter for any Canadian city outside of British Columbia. Precipitation is frequent and often heavy, falling year round. On average, summer is the driest season, with only occasional thunderstorm activity, and the wettest months are from October to January, with December the wettest single month, with nearly 165 millimetres of precipitation on average. The success of its football team made Notre Dame a household name. The success of Note Dame reflected rising status of Irish Americans and Catholics in the 1920s. Catholics rallied up around the team and listen to the games on the radio, especially when it knocked off the schools that symbolized the Protestant establishment in America — Harvard, Yale, Princeton, and Army. Yet this role as high-profile flagship institution of Catholicism made it an easy target of anti-Catholicism. The most remarkable episode of violence was the clash between Notre Dame students and the Ku Klux Klan in 1924. Nativism and anti-Catholicism, especially when directed towards immigrants, were cornerstones of the KKK's rhetoric, and Notre Dame was seen as a symbol of the threat posed by the Catholic Church. Switzerland lies between latitudes 45° and 48° N, and longitudes 5° and 11° E. It contains three basic topographical areas: the Swiss Alps to the south, the Swiss Plateau or Central Plateau, and the Jura mountains on the west. The Alps are a high mountain range running across the central-south of the country, comprising about 60% of the country's total area. The majority of the Swiss population live in the Swiss Plateau. Among the high valleys of the Swiss Alps many glaciers are found, totalling an area of 1,063 square kilometres (410 sq mi). From these originate the headwaters of several major rivers, such as the Rhine, Inn, Ticino and Rhône, which flow in the four cardinal directions into the whole of Europe. Boston has a continental climate with some maritime influence, and using the −3 °C (27 °F) coldest month (January) isotherm, the city lies within the transition zone from a humid subtropical climate (Köppen Cfa) to a humid continental climate (Köppen Dfa), although the suburbs north and west of the city are significantly colder in winter and solidly fall under the latter categorization; the city lies at the transition between USDA plant hardiness zones 6b (most of the city) and 7a (Downtown, South Boston, and East Boston neighborhoods). Summers are typically warm to hot, rainy, and humid, while winters oscillate between periods of cold rain and snow, with cold temperatures. Spring and fall are usually mild, with varying conditions dependent on wind direction and jet stream positioning. As Muslim institutions of higher learning, the madrasa had the legal designation of waqf. In central and eastern Islamic lands, the view that the madrasa, as a charitable endowment, will remain under the control of the donor (and their descendent), resulted in a "spurt" of establishment of madaris in the 11th and 12th centuries. However, in Western Islamic lands, where the Maliki views prohibited donors from controlling their endowment, madaris were not as popular. Unlike the corporate designation of Western institutions of higher learning, the waqf designation seemed to have led to the exclusion of non-orthodox religious subjects such a philosophy and natural science from the curricula. An adolescent 's environment plays a huge role in their identity development . While most adolescent studies are conducted on white , middle class children , studies show that the social and physical experiences of girls and boys differ. One particularly important factor that determines their social identity is the relationship with mother and father . A woman who knows what it is like to go through the stages of pregnancy , labor , and giving birth develops an inner sense of identity as a mother . Research in the U.S . that examines children 's experiences in father and mother-re ared households is focused on the question , Where do children ' s beliefs about relationships with fathers come from ? To extend and consolidate the dynasty 's control in Central Asia , the Kangxi Emperor personally led a series of military campaigns against the Dzungars in Outer Mongolia . The Kangxi Emperor won these campaigns through the application of modern technology using naval battles , land warfare , mining , and the cultivation of new crops and livestock . He also created the capital of his dynasty , Kaifeng , in the northeast part of China . Brief ly , the Kangxi Emperor died in 17 16 . He was succeeded by his son , the Yuan Emperor . The Qing dynasty extended its control over much of Central Asia . The second half of the 1800s was a time of great upheaval in Inner Asia due to the rise of the Russian Empire . It was also a time when the Qing dynasty held its reigns tightly in control , the Kang xi Emperor was no exception . Ka ifeng , the Qing dynasty s capital , was a very beautiful city .

The implications are multiple as various research traditions are now [ when ? ] heavily utilizing the lens of identity to examine phenomena . The Jurassic Period extends from about 201.3 ± 0.2 to 145.0 Ma . During the early Jurassic , the supercontinent Pangaea broke up into the northern supercontinent Laurasia and the southern supercont inent Gond wana . The breakup of Pangaea is an example of a global transition which has profound consequences for both bioge ography and the biogeochemistry of the ocean . It is now widely thought that Pang aea was the most complex ter ra- solid oceanic system to have evolved , for during its demise the seabed was enriched in phosphorus ( P 4 P 2- ) , aluminum ( Al3+ ) , magnesium ( Mg 2+ ) , and silicon ( Si 2 + ) due to the addition of continental crust during its r ecord growth . The super continent P angaea was the mother of the modern continents that emerged during a rapid ocean ic seaway separation during the ensuing Gond wana break up . During the early Jurassic many of the shallow marine deposits were eroded and deposited

The lung gas exchange area is 10 times greater than mammals lungs and is responsible for most of the air exchange between the blood and the lungs . Identity development is a stage in the adolescent life cycle . For most , the search for identity begins in the adolescent years . During these years , adolescents are typically searching for identity in their own way . The process is a way to work things out in a meaningful way and to develop identity . In turn , identity development allows adolescents to develop a sense of identity from which they will build the rest of their world . Unfortunately many adolescents are unable to find their identity or do so in maladapt ive ways . Id en tity development is a unique stage in life which is marked by change and changes in the adolescents life . The need to work through feelings of inadequ acy and loneliness along with changing roles and responsibilities may make adolescents feel extremely lledg and empty . When Nintendo released the NES in the US , the design styling was deliberately different from that of other game consoles . Nintendo wanted to distinguish its product from those that preceded it through aesthetic differences. However , as other manufacturers were creating successful clones , Nintendo came under increasing pressure to produce a more `` standard , `` or standardized , form of home game console . The result was the NES that the US consumer saw in November 1988 , and which Nintendo markets today . To achieve its goals , the `` standard design `` of the NES required a very simple , uniform , and streamlined look . The result was a look the NES quickly became synonymous with . The NES also introduced some unique design features , most notably the joysticks used to control the primary and virtual worlds . Many modern specialty matches have been devised , with unique winning conditions . The most common of these is the ladder match . In the basic ladder match , the first two players start the game as the winners , with a draw in the third round as the third rule . This is sometimes referred to as a `` winner takes all `` match . A more sophisticated form of ladder match is the triangular match . In this example , the winners start the first round as winners , and the losers start the third round . In the third round , players have a tie breaker , and if a third round draw is possible , the loser can choose , after the fourth round , any two players . Another variant is the triple ladder match . This has an open list format , with ties decided by head -to- head finishes , with the loser deciding which two to play . At the 1912 Salon d'Automne an architectural installation was exhibited that quickly became known as Maison Cubiste ( Cubist House ) , signed Raymond Duchamp-Villon and André Mare along with their associate , Henri de Lub icz , who had written their initial letter . The installation consisted of a house consisting of a cube and a sphere , each with a different size , the house of the cube covered in window , whereas the sphere house covered only from the top . The installation was a reaction against the trend to modernise , which was beginning in earnest with the rise of the mechanical revolution and which is characterized by its focus on the new machine . The final major aspect of identity formation is self-esteem . Self-esteem is defined as one 's thoughts and feelings about one 's self-concept and identity . Most theories on self-esteem agree that positive self-esteem is good . In addition , the literature on the relationship between self-esteem and psychopathology focuses largely on the development of psychopathology in childhood . Individuals with high self -esteem are much more likely to avoid risky risky behaviors in life . Self -evaluation has been associated with risk taking and also with antisocial behavior . The polyphony of Christian a cappella music began to develop in Europe around the late 15th century , with compositions by Josquin des Prez . The early a cappella polyphonies became popular in the southern Christ endom of Northern Europe . The early movements usually had two or more voices but in the 17th and 18th centuries , composers began to write works with poly phonic textures . By the beginning of the 20th century , composers were creating settings of classical pieces or other music in a poly phonic style. Many works had been written with two voices for many years but the popularity of a capp ella music around the time of Mahler encouraged composers to explore the potential of polyphony in several voice parts . There were numerous attempts to create larger scales and other textures but only from the mid 20th century did compos ers begin to experiment with more than two parts , which resulted in the development of baro que counterpoint. By far the largest military action in which the United States engaged during this era was the War of 1812 . With Britain locked in a major war with Napoleon and the USA engaged for four years in a defensive struggle with Spain , the government was willing to do what was necessary to achieve the United States victory . The government was able to spend an estimated 9 .8 percent of the population 's income on the fight ; the national debt was no higher than $ 8 million , and nearly half the population supported the war without pay and without question . A large portion of the debt , totaling nearly 90 percent of US government indebtedness today , was financed out of public money . This is of course quite in contrast to any modern war , which requires massive public expenditures , either directly or through taxes , to pay off the war and bring the economy back to full health . Although people often think that memory operates like recording equipment , it is not the case . The molecular mechanisms underlying the induction and maintenance of memory are very dynamic. Memory is based on changes to synaptic strength and is not simply an accumulation of memory traces . This means that memories are more complicated than previously thought . That is why neuro biologists have started to look into how memories work . The idea is to study how memories are formed and maintained at the level of molecular mechanisms . Scientists have just begun to understand how these principles operate and there is much work to be done. Early Modern universities initially continued the curriculum and research of the Middle Ages : natural philosophy , logic , medicine , theology , mathematics , astronomy ( and astrology ) , the sciences of war , literature , history ... It was as though philosophy had been preserved from the dark ages of the Middle Ages . The reason for this was not only the scientific interest created by the printing press , but also the desire in earlier times for better education . And of course as the new universities grew throughout the 1500s , their curricula changed , and their approach to science changed , as well , to suit the new developments in the sciences : astronomy , genetics and so on. The two major types of nonprofit organization are membership and board-only . A membership organization elects the board and has regular meetings and the power to amend the bylaws . Membership organizations are commonly linked to political organizations such as the Democratic party or Republican party ; they are the more common type of organization . Often membership organizations are called `` clubs ``. Board -only organizations often include a few members and have no power from the membership and may be called `` co -ops `` , or societies . Boards usually select new members by appointment by members and new officers when necessary. Because members often play only a minor function , their involvement in an organization is often indirect and shallow to meet the public relations needs of the organization , while the organization itself is free from the public 's direct involvement as a whole . The university culture developed differently in northern Europe than it did in the south , although the northern ( primarily Germany , France and Great Britain ) and southern universities developed more in tandem with each other than their counterparts in northern Europe . Microbiological culture is a principal tool used to diagnose infectious disease . In a microbial culture , a growth medium is provided for a specific agent . A sample taken from a site of infection is added to the medium and allowed to grow . The specimen is checked every hour or so for the appearance and the growth . Typically a growth plate is prepared : the top plate is a thin agar plate ; the agar plate is placed over a sterile culture medium plate ; sterile cover slips are added to the wells in the agar plate for covering the bacteria ; this is also called the bottom plate ... The top plate can be a glass of water , an ag ar plate , a culture dish , a T cell culture plate of the mon onuclear cell monolayer . Calvin continued to take an interest in the French religious affairs from his Paris-based base . He and John Knox met on multiple occasions and discussed common problems with the French Church . Calvin took the view that the most important point for Christians to consider was to be able to practice their religion freely . He had little interest in being a `` Christian monarch '' in France . He was not looking for power or political glory but for a personal spiritual life . He sought to be a spiritual leader with an interest in people and not simply to obtain recognition for his ideas . In fact the French civil conflict gave Calvin a golden opportunity of promoting his view that religion must be kept as a personal matter to which no one could intr ude . He began a crusade against France and its people to free them from their sins .

This view has its roots in an early- 16th- century tradition of natural philosophy ( and especially the philosophical work of the French philosopher Renouvier ) according to which the material world was the fundamental property of nature , that all things which are in the material world must depend for their existence on being material and that all intellectual things derive their existence from being mental , i . e. having immaterial ( mind ) elements in common with the mind that thinks . Under the Capetian dynasty France slowly began to expand its authority over the nobility , growing out of the Île-de-France to exert control over more of the country in the north and on the coast . However with the conquest of Italy ( 1098 ) and Sicily ( 1109 ) and with the continuing struggle with England ( 1137– 60 ) the French crown increasingly became the symbol of state unity , unity on home soil . The Normans in their new homeland of the duchy of Normandy ( 1066 ) with their strong connections to the Carolingian empire established a powerful state within the French crown . Thus by the later th irteenth century the two realms remained two realms with separate institutions in separate dyn asties but a common political system . This was soon challenged by the rise of a new dynasty and kingdom that expanded over France in the person of the House of Val ois . The European concept of `` race '' , along with many of the ideas now associated with the term , arose at the time of the scientific revolution , which began in the seventeenth century . The origin of race comes down to a single moment of individual variation , the emergence of certain traits in one individual which are not present in the same individuals when he is crossed with another individual . The specific term and concept of race arose during the nineteenth century ; before that time , people had different ethnic ities , each with its own appearance , culture , and language . Racial classification , in some form , has been in Europe since the days of the Roman Empire . During the Renaissance , the concept came to mean an ethnicity that was an out growth of Roman law . Successful cultivation of cotton requires a long frost-free period , plenty of sunshine , and a moderate rainfall , usually from 600 to 1,200 mm ( 24 to 47 in ) annually . The soil must be hard and compact to avoid soil run off in the rainy season , during which there can be heavy rain and a high wind . After the rain the soil is soft , susceptible to cracking and root growth , and it becomes easier to waterlog . In the non rain season the soil is damp and has high organic matter content . After a long dry season , during which there was little rain , the soil moisture starts to rise , especially after a cool snap , this is because the root systems have reached the final stage of growth where they have accumulated the nutrients required to survive the dry season . Boundaries can be inclusive or exclusive depending on how they are perceived by other people . An exclusive boundary arises , for example , when a person adopts a marker for defining a shared identity or space that excludes other people . An inclusive boundary , on the other hand , exists when no one is defined by the shared identity , and everyone enjoys equal participation . This article examines the distinction between exclusion and inclusion by focusing on `` out- Of-The -Box `` , socially engaged , international- boundary- stakeholders who engage in activities that go outside of the boundaries . Ex clusion may be defined as any activity that does not represent and /or include other groups . Inclusion is seen as the inclusion of another group . An example of inclusive boundary activities which transcend any group would be the inclusion of people with disabilities in the World Baseball Classic . Peer groups contribute to adolescents ' resilience by providing them with the opportunity to improve their social skills with other members of their respective peers , as well as being an influence on their adolescent behaviors as well as having a positive effect on self-esteem . These groups provide adolescents with a forum in which they can receive critical feedback from their peers in order to develop self- awareness and social competence . Chapter XI deals with evidence from biogeography , starting with the observation that differences in flora and fauna from separate regions can not be explained by environmental differences alone ; for biological species , these can therefore not just be explained by gene flow , but will also result in the spread of different populations . It deals with the problem of interglacial species migration . Chapter XII deals with the question of species selection , the need for species to be adapted to the environment they find themselves in , but also for competition for space , food and mates to cause them to change over time . The third chapter deals with the problem of species loss , particularly of ext inctions which have become rare due to changes in their environment , for example species extinct for 2000 years can be found in the Southern Hemisphere today . Also discussed is the need for biodiversity , for the conservation of which new forms of protection have to be developed .

Sleep does not affect acquisition or recall while one is awake . Therefore , sleep has the greatest effect on memory consolidation . During sleep , the neural connections in the brain are reorganized . During this process , the memories associated with the different items that were initially retrieved during wakefulness may fuse together , allowing them to be retrieved even when the information is not recalled in the conscious state . When reoriented , these neurons are better able to encode the new information . As a result , when the information is recalled , it can be recalled as accurately as it was during the initial retrieval . The vast Seleucid Empire was , like Egypt , mostly dominated by a Greco-Macedonian political elite . The Greek population of the cities who formed the dominant elite were reinforced by new migrants who had come over in waves as the empire expanded eastward ( cf . [ ] ) . But the empire lasted into the 3 rd century BC , and its collapse and resulting transformation of the eastern Mediterranean is still a subject of controversy among scholars today . As cellular metabolism/energy production requires oxygen , potentially damaging ( e.g. , mutation causing ) compounds known as free radicals can form . Most of these are oxidizers ( i.e. oxidizable molecules that lose electrons when they are reduced by any other oxidizer ) . Free radicals are highly reactive and thus tend to damage other molecules ( e .g . enzyme ) , cell structure ( e.g . DNA ) or cellular function ( e . g. protein degradation ) . Free radicals are also carcinogenic and are capable of oxidative damage to the DNA of an organism. Therefore , antioxidants with antioxidant potential are used in medicine to minimize oxidative stress and the potential for damage to cell components . In terms of their use as anti-ob esity or anti -inflammatory agents , it is known that antioxidants inhibit formation of free radicals and also prevent radical -directed protein ( e . g. , DNA ) damage , or at least , these effects are not apparent until after

In 1905 , Lord Curzon split the large province of Bengal into a largely Hindu western half and `` Eastern Bengal and Assam '' , a largely Muslim eastern half . The boundary separating the two halves was not fixed but was based on a set of conventions arrived at by Lord Curzon and an appointed committee of commissioners . The majority of the Hindus were Beng alis settled in the western part ( now Bangladesh ) while the Indians of Ass am were mostly Hindu hillt ribes . Thus the Assames e Muslims were essentially ruled within the territorial boundaries set out by Lord Curzon . Lord Cur zon was given the status of Viceroy of India and was responsible for `` the maintenance of the dignity , independence and integrity of India and for the continuance of its unity . `` He also had to keep the peace between the two communities and to provide protection to both of them . The phenomenalist phase of post-Humean empiricism ended by the 1940s , for by that time it had become obvious that statements about physical things could not be translated into statements about the world of ideas . They could only be translated into statements about physical things , which is to say that the world of ideas was themselves made up primarily of ideas about physical objects . In 1940 , the British philosopher David St ove , in his essay `` Some Mistakes we Never Make , `` gave the following account of this `` empirical turn . `` The mistake that we do make is in using physicalism as a philosophical criterion for truth , for it is the mistake we make by thinking of the physical and the logical as mutually distinct categories . `` Physicalism is simply a mistake , for the world of ideas is a world of ideas in which the physical is but one dimension of reality . The area of modern Zhejiang was outside the major sphere of influence of the Shang civilization during the second millennium BC . The people living in this area were the Jings , who were later absorbed into the Jin , the Rul ers of the Northern Zhou ( the Shang dynasty ) , and the Liu of the Western Zhou ( Shang dynasty ) . The Jings , or a branch of them , founded the Shang dynast ies that lasted from about 1600 BC till the end of the Western Zhou dynasty in the tenth century BC . The Zhou , Liu , or later Han culture also became integrated as a subculture in this area. On 23 April 2014 , the U.S. Federal Communications Commission ( FCC ) was reported to be considering a new rule that will permit ISPs to offer content providers a direct financial transaction path to their broadband subscribers . The proposed new FCC rule ( Public Information Notice 12-06 , filed on 17 January 2014 ) would allow providers to directly provide content providers a direct financial transaction path between their subscribers and content providers over the Internet . This new proposal is known as the Direct Market Access ( D MA ) proposal. As part of its rule making process , the FCC plans to study the D MA proposal and will consider implementing the proposal through a Notice of Proposed Rule making ( NPR M ) . The D MA proposal would significantly alter the Internet broadband delivery infrastructure and would represent a policy choice for the United States . This analysis highlights the potential benefits and dangers faced by the United States if the FCC implements the D MA proposal .

Tensions over rising Polish nationalism and the economic effects of the Continental System led to renewed confrontation with Russia . To enforce his blockade , Napoleon launched an invasion of Russia in June 1812 , hoping to achieve a major victory . The French army , though successful , was badly demoralized after sustaining huge losses fighting against the allies . It then retreated back to France. At the same time , a British and Dutch army , under the command of the Earl of Southampton , attempted to invade France , but met with stiff resistance from the French army . The British-led expedition , however , was eventually stopped , in what would be called the Battle of Waterloo . Napoleon 's defeat in Europe , however , was a turning point in the history of the French Empire , which would lead it to great heights of military success in the following years under the leadership of his nephew , Napoleon Bonaparte ( Napoleon the Second ) . The works of Virgil almost from the moment of their publication revolutionized Latin poetry . The Eclogues , Georgics , and above all the Aeneid became standard texts in school , colleges , and literature courses for decades . In the early nineteenth century , the same kind of reception was shown , and the Latin prose texts of Liv y , Cic ero , Val erius Fl accus , and Ovid were taken by educated persons . A reaction set in . Vir gil 's works , with their explicit references of the gods and goddesses , and his strong anti-Rom ance attitude gave no easy comfort to Christian Rome , where their use to make a case for the Roman gods was deeply alien . This was an age in which a person called himself a Roman , or identified himself with the history of Rome . To read Virgil was to identify oneself with the ancient past and with Rome . In this case , any causal asymmetrical factor that has anything to do with the cup would be absent in the causal history in the second hand . Thus , it is not that a non- arbitrary causal factor , such as a particular individual , is responsible for dropping the cup and as such it has nothing to do with the reason why the cup was shattered or why it was not shattered , since it is impossible to argue for specific causal reasons . The state seemed at relative calm compared to the rest of the country due to its close ties to the United States until 1841 . In 1843 the possibility of a war between Britain and France sparked a diplomatic crisis between the United States and Great Britain that lasted until the war ended , costing the United States approximately $ 20 million . This crisis was triggered not by the threat of war between the United States and France , but rather by the threat of a third party joining in , Spain . The issue of Spain joining the war was not a real possibility as the Spanish Navy was considered too strong to engage British ships , and too weak to resist a combined force of French and American ships . It was thought that by establishing peace , Spain would be left alone since it would be too weak to act . However , the issue of foreign trade and commercial interests also drove the United States to increase defense spending .

The deliberate or accidental hybridising of two or more species of closely related animals through captive breeding is a human activity which has been in existence for millennia and has been documented in the animal Kingdom since ancient times. Some of the more well known instances in the animal world are the introduction of new or exotic wild species into natural environments ; the crossbred hybrids produced for various commercial purposes ; the hybrids produced at the request of captive wildlife management units ( CWM U ) or other institutions within national jurisdictions , ; and the hybrids produced or experimented on because of human whim or for pure `` artistic '' reasons . However , there are situations within wildlife management where a species can be considered `` hybridised `` if its biological properties are so closely related to another species that the resultant embryos would be difficult or impossible to separate or recognize . A number of novel ideas about religion developed with the Enlightenment , including Deism and talk of atheism . Deism , according to Thomas Paine , is the simple belief that there is no such thing as God . Atheism in general was a common and accepted position after the French Revolution . However , there was , at the time , little real discussion of this topic and atheists were rarely taken seriously as religious alternatives . For example , only 10 % of American Atheists have ever been invited to speak at a religious denomination , according to their website . The idea that religion was a choice , a product of human fallibility , was not widely accepted , and religion was frequently equated with immorality , sexual per missiveness , and bad theology . This view remained dominant until the 60s and 70s , as it was in America . These views have not completely disappeared , but society has moved on . Religious institutions still exist , however

The success of its football team made Notre Dame a household name . The success of Note Dame reflected rising status of Irish Americans and Catholics in the 1920s . In 1924 it won a new type of sporting event , a college football world championship . But the college 's long- term future had already been sealed . By 1929 the football school was no longer open . It was absorbed into the Department of the Navy : Naval Academy from which it was relocated to Annapolis Maryland in 1930 . Annapolis became Notre Dame ' s second home . Here , along with some other colleges , an `` ND `` trademark was added to college mascots and team names . By the mid - 1930s there were also new programs , such as a School of Commerce . Switzerland lies between latitudes 45° and 48° N , and longitudes 5° and 11° E. It contains three basic topographical areas : the Swiss Alps to the south , the lake Zug to the north , and the Jura mountains to the west in the direction of France . It has an area of approximately 2,100 km² . On average , the country is 3.2 ° latitude north and south ; its highest point is Bern at an altitude of 1,491 m , and the lowest point is at the Jura to the west at an elevation of 80 m . The terrain has both low and high peaks ; the highest peak in the mountains is the Eiger . Switzerland 's population consists of 36.7 million people spread over 4 , 929 municipal ( prefect ural ) subdiv isions . The country is highly developed as a location due to the many roads and railways that connect it with other European countries . It is also one of the leading tourist destinations in Europe

The summer period is warmer than other Nort heastern cities with a peak period of highs reaching in August ; winter , colder than other cities in the Northeast . As Muslim institutions of higher learning , the madrasa had the legal designation of waqf . In central and eastern Islamic lands , the view that the madrasa , as a nonreligious institution was un -Islamic , was a widespread one . It meant , in some way , that Islam was secular , and that Islam was the religion of the government and its officials , but , in an other more significant way , it was the institution of religious knowledge as a branch of knowledge and a school of faith . It was as a branch of knowledge that it was called the mosque , and as the school of faith that it was called the madras a . This , in essence , meant that madrasas were as much concerned with the world .
